Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: They develop a comprehensive design for a hospital wing, ensuring critical areas like operating rooms and emergency routes function seamlessly.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was sketching the final layout for the new hospital wing. The deadline was tomorrow, and I still needed to double-check the emergency routes and operating room placements. Every detail mattered—lives could depend on this design. But when I glanced at the screen, I saw it was Jamie. I answered, and immediately heard the tremble in their voice. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” Jamie said, barely holding back tears. I knew what was expected of me as a friend: to listen, to be present, to help Jamie through this rough patch. But as an architect, I was expected to focus, to ensure nothing was overlooked in this critical project. My mind raced, torn between the blueprints in front of me and the pain in Jamie’s voice. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, and I sat there, phone in hand, heart pounding, unsure which role to answer first.
